articles.title: SJAA
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) bulletin for January/February 1982 details a packed schedule of events, including multiple indoor and outdoor star parties, often with mirror-making classes and equipment showcases. General meetings feature presentations on topics like a USSR tour including a solar eclipse, Space Shuttle missions, and preparing for Mars opposition. The document also provides club contact information and membership details.

articles.title: OBSERVATIONS
articles.summary: SJAA Bulletin editors Steve Greenberg and Patti Winter call for member contributions and feedback to enhance the publication, while also addressing minor corrections and submission guidelines. The article further includes various club announcements such as issues with Sky & Telescope subscriptions, a request for double star observers for the International Halley Watch, and details on the upcoming annual astronomical auction. Additionally, it features member news, a new observing site, and several classifieds for astronomical equipment.

articles.title: PRESIDENT'S REPORT: WESTERN AMATEUR ASTRONOMERS' WINTER BOARD MEETING
articles.summary: This president's report details the agenda for the upcoming Western Amateur Astronomers (W.A.A.) winter board meeting, focusing primarily on nominations for the G. Bruce Blair Gold Medal, an award for promoting amateur astronomy. It also addresses strategies to improve attendance at W.A.A.'s summer conferences, including proposals for splitting host duties with other organizations like the Riverside Telescope Makers' Conference (RTMC) or the Astronomical Association of Northern California (AANC), and the potential formation of an Astronomical Association of Southern California (AASC). The president solicits input from SJAA members on these important organizational matters.

articles.title: SPACE TELESCOPE TOUR
articles.summary: Approximately ninety members and guests of the SJAA attended a successful tour of the Space Telescope mockup at Lockheed on December 4th. Led by Tom Stcyczynski, the tour provided an informative presentation on the full-sized mockup, which included the telescope's various modules and systems, as well as a smaller Space Shuttle mockup. The event was well-received, with organizers and Lockheed staff receiving special thanks for its success.

articles.title: THE SJAA'S NOVEMBER STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) November star parties were significantly impacted by adverse weather. The first event on the 21st was rained out, leading to an impromptu indoor session. The second, on the 28th, faced cold temperatures and strong winds after initial cloud cover cleared, but attendees still managed some observations with Chuck Olson's new 13.1" Coulter Odyssey I, viewing objects like M51 and M15.

articles.title: A FUNNY THING HAPPENED ON THE WAY TO THE SHUTTLE
articles.summary: Steve Greenberg provides a humorous first-person account of his misadventures while covering the STS-2 space shuttle launch, detailing a series of frustrating travel and logistical mishaps. His journey included lost luggage, accidental entry into restricted areas, mistaken identity mix-ups for tours, and overcrowded "unique" photo opportunities. The article also touches on encounters with persistent Florida wildlife and strict security measures, all presented with a lighthearted, self-deprecating tone.

articles.title: Don Machholz
articles.summary: Don Machholz discusses encountering wildlife and unexpected phenomena while stargazing in wilderness areas. He offers practical advice for dealing with animals, emphasizing that most are more afraid of humans and can be deterred with noise or by avoiding their feeding grounds. The article also touches on other occasional disruptions like brilliant meteors, distant electrical shorts, and artificial satellites.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: Don Machholz's "Comet Comments" column reflects on the cometary landscape at the end of 1981, noting a current lack of new discoveries but recalling a year rich with multiple visible comets. It discusses the recent naming of a 1979 sungrazing comet and promotes the "Comet News Service" newsletter. The article also provides a detailed historical account of the exceptionally bright "Great January Comet" (1910 I), describing its discovery and remarkable visibility.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: Jay Freeman expresses regret that ancient civilizations lacked telescopes to appreciate deep-sky objects, particularly the Horsehead Nebula (B33). The article details the challenging visual observation of this faint dark nebula near Zeta Orionis, providing star-hopping instructions, optimal viewing conditions, and practical tips like using an occulting bar to mitigate glare from bright stars.

articles.title: Members
articles.summary: This document is a listing of members, detailing their last name, first name, address, city, state, zip code, and phone number. The majority of members are located in various cities across California, particularly the San Francisco Bay Area, with a few entries from Washington State. It serves as a contact directory for an organization's members.

articles.title: BULLETIN SUBSCRIBERS
articles.summary: This document presents a list of "BULLETIN SUBSCRIBERS," detailing their names and postal addresses, with some entries also including phone numbers. The list features individuals from various locations across the United States and one international subscriber from Manchester, England. It appears to be an administrative record or mailing list for a publication.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE
articles.summary: This article provides an update on global space activities in late 1981, covering various satellite launches, including RCA's SATCOM-IIIR and the Soviet Venera probes to Venus, alongside a new Soviet record for space missions. It details the European L-SAT project, upcoming Space Shuttle launches and crews for 1982, and a joint Soviet/French mission. The report also highlights NASA's budget cuts, the Department of Defense's space budget surpassing NASA's, and ongoing debates regarding U.S. planetary exploration (notably Galileo) and the future of a manned U.S. space station, concluding with an experiential account of the STS-2 landing.
